The Sanger technique is a DNA sequencing method that uses modified nucleotides to stop DNA synthesis, allowing the sequence of DNA to be read by analyzing fragment lengths.

questions.text: Which class of antibiotics inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by blocking the attachment of aminoacyl-tRNA to the ribosomal A site?

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT TRUE regarding the initiation of translation?

choices.text: eIF3 and 1A stabilize 60s ribosomal subunit to prevent reassociation with 40s.
Methionine tRNA scans mRNA to identify the initiation AUG codon
ATP dependent helicase eIF4A/4B breaks hydrogen bonds to remove the hairpin loops
Association of mRNA with the 43S preinitiation complex forms the 48S initiation complex

questions.solution:
eIF3 and 1A stabilize 40s (not the 60s subunit) ribosomal subunit to prevent reassociation with 60s.

Steps of initiation:

It involves tRNA, rRNA, mRNA, eukaryotic initiation factors (eIFs), GTP, ATP, and amino acids.

1. Ribosomal Dissociation:

  • 80S ribosomes dissociate into 40S and 60S subunits.
  • eIF3 and 1A stabilize 40s ribosomal subunit to prevent reassociation with 60s, allowing other translation initiation factors to associate with the 40S subunit. (Option A)

2. Formation of the 43S Preinitiation Complex:

  • Binary complex is formed by binding of GTP and eIF-2.
  • This binary complex then binds to methionyl tRNA.
  • The GTP-eIF-2-tRNAi ternary complex binds to the 40S ribosomal subunit to form the 43S preinitiation complex.

3. Formation of the 48S Initiation Complex:

  • The 5′ termini of mRNA molecules in eukaryotic cells are “capped.” The binding of mRNA to the 43S preinitiation complex is facilitated by 7meG-cap.
  • 4G/4A attaches to the cap through 4E, which forms 4F.
  • ATP-dependent helicase eIF4A/4B breaks hydrogen bonds to remove the hairpin loops and make mRNA single-stranded. (Option C ruled out)
  • Methionine tRNA scans the mRNA to identify the initiation AUG codon, and attach the tRNA to AUG at the P site. (Option B ruled out)
  • The association of mRNA with the 43S preinitiation complex forms the 48S initiation complex. (Option D ruled out)

4. Formation of the 80S Initiation Complex:

  • The 60S ribosomal subunit binds to the 48S initiation complex by hydrolysis of the GTP bound to eIF-2 by eIF-5.
  • This results in the release of the initiation factors bound to the 48S initiation complex.
  • The rapid association of the 40S and 60S subunits forms the 80S ribosome.
  • At this point, the met-tRNAi is on the P site of the ribosome, ready for the elongation cycle to commence

questions.text:
Match the following phases of translation (Column A) with the events involved (Column B).


	
		
			
			Column A
			
			
			Column B
			
		
		
			
			1. Elongation
			
			
			a. RF1 binds with RF3 and GTP
			
		
		
			
			2. Initiation
			
			
			b. Binding of aminoacyl-tRNA to the ribosome's A site
			
		
		
			
			3. Termination
			
			
			c. Methionine tRNA scans mRNA for AUG codon
questions.solution:
Phases of translation

Key events

Initiation
  • Dissociation of 80s ribosome into 60s and 40s, and stabilized by various initiation factors.
  • Formation of the 43S Preinitiation Complex: The 40S ribosomal subunit, in association with initiation factors, binds to the initiator tRNA (carrying methionine in eukaryotes or formyl-methionine in prokaryotes)forming the 43S preinitiation complex.
  • Formation of 48S initiation complex: The 43S complex binds to the 5' end of the mRNA, and scans for start codon which upon recognition, the 48S initiation complex is formed.
  • Formation of the 80S Initiation Complex: Binding of the 60S ribosomal subunit to the 48S initiation. The met-tRNA on the P site of the ribosome is ready for the elongation cycle.

Elongation
  • Binding of Aminoacyl-tRNA to the A Site
  • Peptide Bond Formation
  • Elongation factor 2 (EF2) binds to and displaces the peptidyl tRNA from the A site to the P site

Termination
  • Ribosome reaches the terminator codon sequence (UAA, UAG or UGA)
  • Releasing factor(RF1), (RF3) and GTP complex promotes hydrolysis releasing the protein and the tRNA from the P site.

questions.text: Sickle cell anaemia is suspected in a 25-year-old patient who presents with episodes of abdominal pain and fatigue. Genetic analysis reveals GAG in the 6th position is replaced with GTG. Which type of mutation here results in haemoglobin that is still functional but altered?
questions.solution:
• The mutation described is a missense mutation, where the GAG codon (which codes for glutamic acid) is replaced by the GTG codon (which codes for valine) at the 6th position of the hemoglobin gene resulting in the production of hemoglobin S (HbS) instead of the normal hemoglobin A (HbA).
  • This partially acceptable mutation still allows the hemoglobin to carry oxygen, but with altered efficiency (accumulation of globin chains and causes sickling crisis on exposure to deoxygenation.), leading to symptoms of sickle cell anemia.
  • Sickle cell anemia is an example of point mutation, transversion, missense and partially acceptable mutation.

Effects on the functioning of the protein:

Based on the Effects on the function of protein

Acceptable mutation: (Option C ruled out)

Partially acceptable mutation: (Option B)

Unacceptable mutation: (Option A ruled out)

Change in the nucleotide sequence causes alteration in the amino sequence that does not affect the functioning of the protein.

Example: Hb Sydney

Change in the nucleotide sequence causing alteration in the amino sequence that affects the functioning of the protein but it is not immediately life-threatening.

Example: HbS - GAG is replaced by GTG which replaces the glutamic acid to valine.

Change in the nucleotide sequence causes alteration in the amino sequence that affects the functioning of the protein so extensively that it is immediately life-threatening.

Example: Congenital methemoglobinemia (HbM) - Histidine (CAU) is replaced with tyrosine (UAU) in alpha-chain.

Nonsense mutation (Option D): Codon for an amino acid is mutated to a termination codon (UAA or UAG) causing premature termination of translation.

A mutation is defined as a change in the nucleotide sequence of DNA.

Frameshift mutation (Option A)

Substitution of one nucleotide by another.

  • Transition (Option C ruled out): A purine is replaced by a purine, and a pyrimidine is replaced by a pyrimidine.
  • Transversion: Purine is replaced by a pyrimidine and vice versa.

Deletion (Option A ruled out) or insertion (Option D ruled out) of nucleotides leads to an altered reading frame in the mRNA.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately reflects a difference between DNA and RNA, considering their roles in genetic information processing and stability?

choices.text: RNA's 2'-hydroxyl group enhances its stability compared to DNA.
RNA polymerases need a primer; DNA polymerases do not.
RNA forms complex structures; DNA remains a double helix
DNA degrades more rapidly than RNA due to the presence of a 2'-hydroxyl group.

questions.solution:
RNA Structure: RNA is single-stranded but can fold into complex three-dimensional structures due to intrachain base pairing (A-U, G-C). DNA is typically double-stranded with a stable double-helix structure.

DNA follows both Chargaff rule of base pairing and Watson and Crick base pairing rule.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding codons?


	A, G, T, C are RNA nucleotides
	A, G, T, C are DNA nucleotides
	A, G, U, C are RNA nucleotides
	A, G, U, C are DNA nucleotides
questions.solution:
A, G, T, and C are nucleotides forming DNA codons, while A, G, U, and C are those forming RNA codons.

Aspect

Details

Codon

Three-nucleotide sequence in mRNA

Codon Functions

Specifies an amino acid sequence in proteins.

Start codon (AUG): Signals the initiation of protein synthesis.

Stop codons(UAA, UAG, and UGA): Signals termination of protein synthesis

Total Codons

64 (4 nucleotides, each position can be A, U, G, or C)

DNA Nucleotides

A, G, T, C   (Options A, C, D ruled out)

RNA Nucleotides

A, G, U (replaces T), C  (Options A, C, D ruled out)

Amino Acid Codons

Reading Frame

mRNA sequence read from start codon to stop codon (Open Reading Frame)

questions.text: The wobble phenomenon in tRNA decoding is primarily due to:

choices.text: Inosine forming non-standard base pairs at the third codon position.
The exact matching of all three nucleotides between codon and anticodon.
Single tRNA binds only to one specific codon.
The rigid Watson-Crick base pairing at the third position of the codon.

questions.solution:
The wobble phenomenon is due to inosine's ability to form non-standard base pairs (with U, C, and A) at the third position of the codon, allowing a single tRNA to recognize multiple codons.

Wobble Phenomenon

  • Definition: Flexible base-pairing between the third nucleotide of a codon (mRNA) and the corresponding nucleotide of the tRNA anticodon. (Option B ruled out)
  • Function: Allows one tRNA molecule to bind to multiple codons coding for the same amino acid. (Option C ruled out)
  • Inosine (I): A modified nucleotide in some tRNA anticodons, pairs with U, C, and A.
  • Non-standard pairing is more flexible than Watson-Crick base pairing, which is strict for the first two codon nucleotides.

Codon Position

Standard Base Pairing

Wobble Pairing

Example

1st and 2nd

Watson-Crick rules

(Option D ruled out)

Strict

AGA and AGG code for Arginine.

3rd

Non-standard pairing

Flexible

AGA/AGG with UCU, GGU/GGC/GGA with CCI

questions.text: In the context of genetic code degeneracy, which of the following accurately describes its impact on protein synthesis?

choices.text: Single codon specifies one amino acid.
Multiple codons can code for the same amino acid.
Flexibility occurs at the 2nd codon position.
Inosine in mRNA contributes to the flexibility in pairing.

questions.solution:
Degeneracy allows multiple codons to specify the same amino acid, based on flexible base-pairing rules.

Degeneracy in the Genetic Code:

  • Multiple codons can encode the same amino acid. (Option A ruled out) (Option B)
  • There are 64 possible codons but only 20 amino acids.
  • Example: Six codons (UCU, UCC, UCA, UCG, AGU, AGC) all code for serine.

Causes of Degeneracy:

  • Wobble Hypothesis: Flexibility in base-pairing rules between the third nucleotide of mRNA codon and the tRNA anticodon. (Option C ruled out)
  • Inosine (I) Role: Inosine in tRNA anticodons can pair with U, C, and A, enhancing code flexibility. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the primary mechanisms and applications of RNA interference (RNAi)?

choices.text: Degradation of mRNA; used for gene manipulation and therapy.
Enhancement of mRNA synthesis; used for genetic modifications.
Conversion of mRNA to DNA; used for protein structure studies.
Stabilisation of mRNA; used for treating infections.

questions.solution:
RNAi primarily functions through mRNA degradation and inhibiting protein synthesis, with gene manipulation and therapy applications.

RNA Interference (RNAi)

  • Definition: Biological process where double-stranded RNA (dsRNA) silences specific gene expressions.
  • Mechanisms:
    • Degradation of messenger RNA (mRNA) molecules corresponding to the target gene.
    • Reduction of expression levels of the target gene.
  • Applications:
    • Tool in genetic research and biotechnology for gene knockdown.
    • Understanding gene function.
    • Developing therapeutic strategies.

 

Enhancement of mRNA synthesis; used for genetic modifications (Option B) does not enhance mRNA synthesis; it silences gene expression.

Conversion of mRNA to DNA; used for protein structure studies (Option C) does not involve converting mRNA to DNA; it targets mRNA for degradation

Stabilisation of mRNA; used for treating infections (Option D) causes degradation of mRNA, not stabilisation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the synthesis of mRNA?

choices.text: Introns are the coding sequence in a mRNA
7-methyl guanosine gets added to the 3’ end of mRNA
Process of splicing occurs in the cytoplasm
Heteronuclear RNA is not a functional mRNA

questions.solution:
Heteronuclear RNA (hnRNA) (Primary transcript)is the immediate product of transcription and is the precursor to mRNA, containing introns and exons. It undergoes processing like splicing, capping, and polyadenylation to become functional mRNA.

Synthesis of mRNA:

Introns are the coding sequence in a mRNA (Option A): Exons are the coding sequences, while introns are the non-coding sequences in a mRNA.

7-methyl guanosine gets added to the 3’ end of mRNA (Option B): 7-methyl guanosine gets added to the 5’ end of mRNA, while Poly-A tail gets added to the 3’ end of mRNA.

Process of splicing occurs in the cytoplasm (Option C): Process of splicing occurs in the nucleus.

questions.text: Which of the following steps in the process of tRNA synthesis occurs in the cytoplasm?

choices.text: Rearrangement of glycosidic linkages giving rise to pseudouridine
Fourth post-transcriptional modification of random methylation
Aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases attach the amino acid

questions.solution:
The 7th post-transcriptional modification involves aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases attaching the amino acid to the tRNA, making it functional in the cytoplasm.

Synthesis of tRNA:

 

Rearrangement of glycosidic linkages giving rise to pseudouridine (Option A) is incorrect because pseudouridine formation occurs in the nucleus, as part of post-transcriptional modifications of tRNA.

Deamination creating inosine (Option B) is incorrect because inosine is formed in the nucleus by the deamination of adenosine during tRNA maturation. Inosine is important for wobble base pairing in codon recognition.

Fourth post-transcriptional modification of random methylation (Option C) is incorrect because methylation of tRNA (as part of modifications like methylation of ribose or bases) occurs in the nucleus, not the cytoplasm.

questions.text: Which statement best describes the wobble hypothesis in relation to tRNA's function?

choices.text: Allows multiple tRNAs to bind to a single codon.
Explains tRNA's ability to bind to any codon with perfect complementarity.
Single tRNA recognizes multiple codons due to flexible base pairing.
Accounts for varying tRNA lengths matching different mRNA sequences.

questions.solution:
The Wobble Hypothesis explains that a single tRNA can bind to multiple codons because of flexible base pairing at the third position of the codon.

tRNA / transfer RNA:

Component

Description

Function

Amino Acid Acceptor Arm

Located at the 3' end, ending in CCA, which is added post-transcriptionally. The amino acid is attached to the 3′-OH group of the A moiety.

Charging: Amino acids are attached to the tRNA by aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases for protein synthesis.

D Arm

Contains dihydrouridine, a modified base. Contributes to the overall structure and recognition of tRNA by its corresponding aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase.

Recognition: Ensures correct aminoacylation by interacting with aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase.

TψC Arm

Named for its ribothymidine (T), pseudouridine (ψ), and cytidine (C) content. Involved in binding tRNA to the ribosome.

Binding: Positions tRNA correctly at the ribosome for protein synthesis.

Anticodon Loop

Opposite the amino acid acceptor arm, contains a sequence of three nucleotides (anticodon) complementary to the codon on mRNA.
 

Wobble phenomenon

  • Third nucleotide pair formation is non-specific (more than one codon coding for a single amino acid)

(Or)

  • Reduced stringency when the third nucleotide pair is formed between codon and anti-codon.

(Or)

  • When tRNA is written in 5’, 3’ direction, the first nucleotide of the anticodon of tRNA is not specific

Degeneracy

More than one codon coding for a single amino acid because of the wobble phenomenon.

Codon Recognition: Ensures the correct amino acid is added to the polypeptide chain during translation.

Variable Arm

Located between the TψC arm and the anticodon loop. Its length varies among different tRNA species and contributes to the tertiary structure of tRNA.

Structural Flexibility: Aids in interactions with the ribosome and other translation factors.

Allows multiple tRNAs to bind to a single codon (Option A): The wobble hypothesis focuses on how a single tRNA can recognize and bind to several codons that code for the same amino acid, not how multiple tRNAs interact with one codon.

Explains tRNA's ability to bind to any codon with perfect complementarity (Option B): The wobble hypothesis involves flexible or non-standard base pairing. It does not imply that tRNAs bind with perfect complementarity to all codons.

Accounts for varying tRNA lengths matching different mRNA sequences (Option D): The hypothesis does not address differences in tRNA lengths or their relationship with mRNA sequences.

questions.text: Which of the following types of rRNA is associated with the 40S ribosomal subunit in eukaryotic cells?
questions.solution:
• ​​​​​In eukaryotic cells, the ribosome is composed of two subunits: the small 40S subunit and the large 60S subunit.
  • The 40S subunit contains the 18S rRNA, which is essential for the structural integrity and function of the ribosome during protein synthesis.
  • The 60S subunit, on the other hand, includes the 5S, 5.8S, and 28S rRNAs (Options A and C ruled out)
  • The 16S rRNA is found in the small subunit of prokaryotic ribosomes, not in eukaryotic ribosomes (Option D ruled out)

Type of RNA

Characteristics

Function

mRNA (messenger RNA)
  • Single-stranded
  • Varies in length depending on the encoded protein
  • Contains exons and introns (in eukaryotes)
  • Carries genetic information from DNA to the ribosome
  • Encodes the amino acid sequence of proteins
  • Undergoes processing such as capping, polyadenylation, and splicing in eukaryotes

tRNA (transfer RNA)
  • Small, typically 73-93 nucleotides
  • Cloverleaf structure
  • Contains an anticodon and an amino acid attachment site
  • Transfers specific amino acids to the ribosome during protein synthesis
  • Recognizes codons on mRNA through its anticodon region
  • Plays a critical role in translating the genetic code into protein

rRNA (ribosomal RNA)
  • Forms the core of ribosome's structure
  • Eukaryotic ribosomes: 18S (40S subunit), 5.8S, 28S, 5S (components of the 60S subunit)
  • Prokaryotic ribosomes: 16S, 23S, 5S
  • Major structural and functional components of ribosomes
  • Catalyzes peptide bond formation during protein synthesis

snRNA (small nuclear RNA)
  • Small, usually less than 200 nucleotides
  • Found in the nucleus
  • Component of the spliceosome
  • Involved in the processing of pre-mRNA in eukaryotes
  • Essential for splicing introns from pre-mRNA

miRNA (microRNA)
  • Small, approximately 22 nucleotides
  • Single-stranded
  • Forms hairpin structures
  • Regulates gene expression post-transcriptionally
  • Binds to complementary sequences on target mRNAs, resulting in translational repression or mRNA degradation
  • Plays a role in various biological processes including development, differentiation, and apoptosis

siRNA (small interfering RNA)
  • Short, double-stranded RNA, about 20-25 nucleotides
  • Originates from longer double-stranded RNA
  • Involved in the RNA interference (RNAi) pathway
  • Mediates the degradation of specific mRNAs
  • Used experimentally to silence gene expression
